title: How can a poem have 1 stanza? - Quora

response.answer_text: A poem can absolutely have one stanza! Shakespeare wrote a ton of them!! One of his, the classic “Sonnet 18″, is below, in all its single-stanza’d glory… Sonnet 18by William Shakespeare Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?Thou art more lovely and more temperate:Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,And summer’s lease hath all too short a date;Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;And every fair from fair sometime declines,By chance or nature’s changing course untrimm'd;But thy eternal summer shall not fade,Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow’st;Nor shall death brag thou wander’st in his shade,When in eternal lines to time thou grow’st: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see, So long lives this, and this gives life to thee. source: Poetry Foundation Single-stanza poetry is widely varied in its different forms, as others have already answered. I find them a great way to create a punchy, pithy kind of poetry because you don’t have a lot of time (space) to get to your point! That being stated, of course, one stanza should not be a free verse poem of like 100 lines with no paragraph break. To me that’s cheating, and brutal for your (reading) audience. If a stanza goes any farther beyond the 14 lines length of something like a sonnet, well, that’s sort of begging for a break imho. Two-stanza poems are perfectly fine, too! In fact, they’re a great form for certain specific purposes (as are poems of three stanzas).  (Here’s an interesting deconstruction of some Shakespeare sonnets, btw, that I found while going over to get my copypasta of 18… https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/47051/the-essential-shakespeare-volume-xii-space-saver-sonnets)

There are many styles of poems and, like Cal stated, they can do pretty much what they want to do. Like Kayla mentioned, there is the Haiku, which is a 3-line short poem that uses sensory language to capture a feeling, or image. It is often inspired by an element of nature, a moment of beauty, or another poignant experience. The first line has 5 syllables, the second has 7, the last has 5. An example of a Haiku: Whitecaps on the bay:A broken signboard bangingIn the April wind.[Anonymous]And let’s not forget the Senryu, (one of my personal favorites), which like the Haiku, also has three lines. The first line has 5 syllables, the second with 7, and the last has 5, like the first. Two examples of a Senryu: Hypocritical: To proclaim a Godly self, yet write hate in verse.[by CJ Heck]Take everyday wordsbeyond everyday talentand write them alive.[by CJ Heck]You can also just have a single stanza poem, such as these below: MemoryMemory is a fragile thing;A bee’s honey, and its sting.[by Violet Wiggins Newton]FriendsSome are true;Others are not.They’ll either love you,Or what you’ve got.[by Bea Myers]I hope this helps you!

Of course. A poem can have as many or as few as the writer needs. This is an unpublished poem of mine that is just one stanza. The trees have shed their fancy dress Forced by nature to confess Their broken boughs and empty nests. A fate that shall befall not me, For all the secrets I possess Are locked cold and deep inside my chest. Also, this poem by Emily Dickenson: There is no Frigate like a Book To take us lands away Nor any Coursers like a Page Of prancing Poetry— This Traverse may the poorest take Without oppress of Toll— How frugal is the Chariot That bears the Human Soul —

Why not 1 stanza? A poem can do anything it wants to do, have as many lines as it wants to have. A poem can make up its own rules, and if it wants to have only 1 stanza, it can have one stanza, like s sonnet, for example, the best form for poetry that has been created yet.
